ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Working on an independent research project in electrical engineering
I learned how to design and improve an electrical engineering project from start to finish.

I learned how to work with a professor to independently conduct a research project. I was able to learn new technologies associated with other engineering disciplines (such as chemical engineering) that my research advisor introduced me to, thereby broadening my perspective into a more multidisciplinary research project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was very flexible and had lots of feedback. Great course.

Research is largely self-guided as long as you get approval from the DUS, so what you make of the course is up to you. For a fulfilling research project, find a professor who does work that you're interested in, or conduct your own passion project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is very fun to work on an independent project.

Yes. This course is a requirement for non-ABET majors, but it is a great way to explore different EE fields that you are interested in, or conduct a fun EE-related project you've always been interested in and receive a credit and a grade for it.
